Tie her to earth, feare be a ſtranger to her,
And all weake bloods affections, but thy hope
Let her bequeath to women: heare me heaven,
Give her a ſpirit maſculine, and noble,
Fit for your ſelves to aske, and mee to offer.
O let her meete my blow, doate on her death;
And as a wanton vine bowes to the pruner,
That by his cutting off more may encreaſe,
So let her fall to raiſe me fruit; hale woman.
The happieſt, and the beſt (if thy dull will
Do not abuſe thy fortune) France ere found yet.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: She is more then dull Sir, leſſe and worſe then woman,
That may inherit ſuch an infinite
As you propound, a greatneſſe ſo neare goodneſſe;
And brings a will to rob her.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Tell me this then,
Was there ere woman yet, or may be found,
That for faire ſame, unſpotted memory,
For vertues ſake, and onely for it ſelfe ſake
Has, or dare make a ſtory?

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Many dead Sir,
Living I thinke as many.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Say, the kingdome
May from a womans will receive a bleſſing,
The king and kingdome, not a private ſafety.
A generall bleſſing Lady.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: A generall curſe
Light on her heart denyes it.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Full of honor;
And ſuch examples as the former ages
Were but dim ſhadowes of, and empty figures.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: You ſtrangely ſtir me Sir, and were my weakeneſſe
In any other fleſh but modeſt womans,
You ſhould not aske more queſtions may I do it?

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: You may, and which is more, you muſt.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: I joy in't,
A bove a moderate gladneſſe, Sir, you promiſe
It ſhall be honeſt.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: As ever time diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Let it be what it may then, what it dare,
I have a minde will hazard it.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: But harke yee,
What may that woman merit, makes this bleſſing!

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Onely her duty Sir

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: 'Tis terrible.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo much the more noble.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: 'Tis full of fearefull ſhaddowes.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: So is ſleepe Sir,
Or any thing that's meerely ours and mortall,
We were begotten gods elſe; but thoſe feares
Feeling but once the fiers of nobler thoughts,
Fly like the ſhapes of clouds we forme to nothing

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Suppoſe it death.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: And endleſſe parting
With all we can call ours, with all our ſweetneſſe,
With youth, ſtrength, pleaſure, people, time, nay reaſon:
For in the ſilent grave, no converſation,
No joyfull tread of friends, no voyce of lovers,
No carefull fathers councell, nothing's hard,
Nor nothing is, but all oblivion,
Duſt and an endleſſe darkneſſe; and dare you woman
Deſire this place?

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: 'Tis of all ſleepes the ſweeteſt,
Children begin it to us, ſtrong men ſeeke it,
And kings from heigth of all their painted glories
Fall like ſpent exhaltations, to this center;
And thoſe are fooles that feare it, or imagine
A few unhandſome pleaſures, or lifes profits
Can recompence this place; and mad that ſtaies it,
Till age blow out their lights, or rotten humors.
Bring them deſpers'd to the earth.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Then you can ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: As willingly as ſay it.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Martell, a wonder,
Here is a woman that dares die, yet tel me,
Are you a wife?

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: I am Sir.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: And have children,
She ſighes and weepes.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: O none Sir.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Dare you venter
For a poore barren praiſe you ne're ſhall heare,
To part with theſe ſweet hopes.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: With all but Heaven;
And yet die full of children; he that reads me
When I am aſhes, is my ſon in wiſhes,
And thoſe chaſte dames that keepe my memory,
Singing my yearely requiems, are my daughters.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Then there is nothing wanting but my knowledge,
And what I muſt doe Lady.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: You are the King Sir,
And what you doe i'le ſuffer, and that bleſſing
That you deſire the Gods ſhowre on the Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Thus much before I ſtrike then, for I muſt kill you,
The Gods have will'd it ſo, they'r made the bleſſing
Muſt make France young againe, and mee a man,
Keepe up your ſtrength ſtill nobly.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Feare me not.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: And meet death like a meaſure.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: I am ſtedfaſt.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt bee ſainted woman, and thy tombe
Cut out in Criſtall, pure and good as thou art;
And on it ſhall be graven every age,
Succeeding Peeres of France that riſe by thy fall,
Tell thou lieſt there like old and fruitfull nature.
Dareſt thou behold thy happineſſe?

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: I dare Sir.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Ha? Pulls off her vaile, letts fall his ſword.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Sir, you muſt not doe it.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: No, I dare not.
There is an Angell keepes that paradice,
A fiery Angell friend; O vertue, vertue,
Ever and endleſſe vertue.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Strike Sir, ſtrike;
And if in my poore death faire France may merit,
Give me a thouſand blowes, be killing mee
A thouſand dayes.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Firſt let the earrh be barren,
And man no more remembred, riſe Ordella,
The neereſt to thy maker, and the pureſt
That ever dull fleſh ſhewed us,— O my heart-ſtrings. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I ſee you full of wonder, therefore nobleſt,
And trueſt amongſt women, I will tell you
The end of this ſtrange accident.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Amazement
Has ſo much wove upon my heart, that truly
I feele my ſelfe unfit to heare, O Sir,
My Lord has ſlighted me.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: O no ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Rob'd me of ſuch a glory by his pitie
And moſt unprovident reſpect.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Deare Lady,
It was not meant to you.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Elſe where the day is,
And houres diſtinguiſh time, time runnes to ages,
And ages end the world, I had been ſpoken.

sp.speaker: Devi.
sp.l: I'le tell you what it was, if but your patience
Will give me hearing.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: If I have tranſgreſt,
Forgive me Sir.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Your noble Lord was counſell'd,
Grieving the barrenneſſe betweene you both,
And all the Kingdome with him, to ſeeke out
A man that knew the ſecrets of the Gods,
Hee went, found ſuch a one, and had this anſwer,
That if hee woo'd have iſſue, on this morning,
For this houre was prefixt him, hee ſhould kill
The firſt hee met being female, from the temple;
And then hee ſhould have children, the miſtake
Is now too perfect Lady.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Still 'tis I Sir,
For may this worke bee done by common women,
Durſt any but my ſelfe that knew the bleſſing,
And felt the benefit, aſſume this thing
In any other, t'ad bin loſt, and nothing,
A curſe and not a bleſſing; I was figur'd;
And ſhall a litle fondneſſe barre my purchaſe?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Where ſhould he then ſeeke children?

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Where they are
In wombes ordain'd for iſſues, in thoſe beauties
That bleſſe a marriage bed, and makes it proceed
With kiſſes that conceive, and fruitfull pleaſures;
Mine like a grave, buries thoſe loyall hopes,
And to a grave it covets.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: You are too good,
Too excellent, too honeſt; robbe not us
And thoſe that ſhall hereafter ſeek example,
Of ſuch ineſtimable worthies in woman,
Your Lord of ſuch obedience, all of honor
In coveting a cruelty is not yours,
A will ſhort of your wiſedome; make not error
A tombe ſtone of your vertues, whoſe faire life
Deſerves a conſtellation: your Lord dare not,
He cannot, ought not, muſt not run this hazard,
He makes a ſeperation nature ſhakes at,
The Gods deny, and everlaſting juſtice
Shrinkes backe, and ſheathes her ſword at.

sp.speaker: Ordella,
sp.l: All's but talke Sir,
I find to what I am reſerv'd, and needfull,
And though my Lords compaſſion makes me poore,
And leaves me in my beſt uſe, yet a ſtrength
Above mine owne, or his dull fondneſſe finds me,
The Gods have given it to mee.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Selfe deſtruction,
Now all good Angells bleſſe thee, O ſweet Lady,
You are abus'd, this is a way to ſhame you,
And with you all that knowes you, all that loves you,
To ruine all you build, would you bee famous,
Is that your end?

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: I would be what I ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Live and confirme the Gods then, live and be loaden
With more than olive beare, or fruitfull Autumn;
This way you kill your merit, kill your cauſe,
And him you would raiſe life to, where, or how
Got you theſe bloudy thoughts? what Devill durſt
Looke on that Angell face, and tempt? doe you know
What 'tis to dye thus, how you ſtrike the ſtarres,
And all good things above? doe you feele
What followes a ſelfe blood, whether you venter,
And to what puniſhment? excellent Lady,
Be not thus cozen'd, doe not foole your ſelf,
The Prieſt was never his owne ſacrifice,
But he that thought his hell here.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: I am counſell'd,

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: And I am glad on't, lye I know you dare not.

sp.speaker: Ordelld.
sp.l: I never have done yet.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Pray take my comfort,
Was this a ſoule to loſe? two more ſuch women
Would ſave their ſexe; ſee, ſhee repents and prayes,
O heare her, heare her, if there bee a faith
Able to reach your mercies, ſhe hath ſent it.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Now good Martell confirme me.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I will Lady,
And every houre adviſe you, for I doubt
Whether this plot bee heavens, or hells; your mother
And I will find it, if it be in mankind
To ſearch the center of it: in the meane time
I'le give you out for dead, and by your ſelfe,
And ſhew the inſtrument, ſo ſhall I find
A joy that will betray her.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Doe what's fitteſt;
And I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Then ever live
Both able to ingroſſe all love, and give.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: I am in labour
To be delivered of that burthenous project
I have ſo long gone with; ha, here's the mid-wife,
Or life, or death.

sp.speaker: Lecure.
sp.l: If in the ſuppoſition
Of her death in whoſe life you die, yo • aske me,
I thinke you are ſafe.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Is ſhe dead?

sp.speaker: Lecure.
sp.l: I have us'd
All meanes to make her ſo, I ſaw him waiting
At the temple doore, and us'd ſuch art within,
That only ſhe of all her ſexe, was firſt
Given up unto his fury.

sp.speaker: Brun,
sp.l: Which if love
Or feare made him forbeare to execute
The vengeance he determin'd, his fond pity
Shall draw it on himſelfe, for were there left
Not any man but hee to ſerve my pleaſures,
Or from mee to receive commands, which are
The joyes for which I love life, he ſhould be
Remov'd, and I alone left to bee Queene
O're any part of goodneſſe that's left in me.

sp.speaker: Lecure.
sp.l: If you are ſo reſolv'd, I have provided
A meanes to ſhip him hence: looke upon this,
But touch it ſparingly, for this once us'd.
Say but to dry a teare, will keepe the eye lyd
From cloſing, untill death performe that office.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Giv't mee, I may have uſe of it, and on you
I'le make the firſt experiment: if one ſigh
Or heavy looke beget the leaſt ſuſpition,
Childiſh compaſſion can thaw the ice
Of your ſo long congeal'd and flinty hardneſſe.
Slight, goe on conſtant, or I Shall.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.l: Beſt Lady,
Wee have no faculties which are not yours.

sp.speaker: Lecure.
sp.l: Nor will bee any thing without you.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Be ſo, and we will ſtand or fall together, for
Since wee, have gone ſo farre, that death muſt ſtay
The journey which we wiſh ſhould never end,
And innocent, or guilty we muſt die,
When we doe ſo, let's know the reaſon why.

sp.speaker: Lecure.
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: We'le be alone.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.l: I would I had
A convoy too, to bring me ſafe off,
For rage although it bee allaid with ſorrow,
Appeares ſo dreadfull in him, that I ſhake
To looke upon it.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Coward, I will meet it,
And know from whence t'as birth: ſonne, kingly Thierry.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Is cheating growne ſo common among men,
And thrives ſo well here, that the Gods endeavour
To practiſe it above?

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Your mother.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Ha! or are they onely carefull to revenge,
Not to reward? or when for your offences
We ſtudy ſatisfaction, muſt the cure
Be worſe then the diſeaſe?

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Will you not heare me?

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: To loſe the ability to performe thoſe duties
For which I entertain'd the name of huſband,
Ask'd more then common ſorrow; but t'impoſe
For the redreſſe of that defect, a torture
In marking her to death, for whom alone
I felt that weakneſſe as a want, requires
More then the making the head bald? or falling
Thus flat upon the earth, or curſing that way,
Or praying this, oh ſuch a ſceane of griefe,
And ſo ſet downe, (the world the ſtage to act on)
May challenge a Tragedian better practis'd
Then I am to expreſſe it; for my cauſe
Of paſſion is ſo ſtrong, and my performance
So weake, that though the part bee good, I feare
Th'ill acting of it, will defraud it of
The poore reward it may deſerve, mens pity.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: I have given you way thus long, a King, and what
Is more, my ſonne, and yet a ſlave to that
Which onely triumphs over cowards ſorrow
For ſhame looke up.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: I'ſt you, looke downe on me;
And if that you are capable to receive it,
Let that returne to you, that have brought forth
One mark'd out only for it: what are theſe?
Come they upon your priviledge, to tread on
The tombe of my afflictions?

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.l: No not wee Sir.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: How dare you then omit the ceremony
Due to the funerall of all my hopes,
Or come unto the marriage of my ſorrowes,
But in ſuch colours as may ſort with them.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.l: Alas; we will weare any thing.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: This is madneſſe,
Take but my counſell.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Yours? Dare you againe
Though arm'd with the authority of a mother,
Attempt the donger that will fall on you
If ſuch another ſillable awake it?
Goe, and with yours be ſafe, I have ſuch cauſe
Of griefe, nay more, to love it, that I will not
Have ſuch as theſe be ſharers in it.

sp.speaker: Lecure.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.l: Another time were better.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Doe not ſtirre,
For I muſt bee reſolv'd and will, be ſtatues.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: I, thou art welcome, and upon my ſoule
Thou art an honeſt man; doe you ſee, he has teares
To lend to him whom prodigall expence
Of ſorrow has made bankerout of ſuch treaſure,
Nay thou doeſt well.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I would it might excuſe.
The ill I bring along.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Thou makeſt me ſmile
In the height of my calamities, as if
There could be the addition of an Atome
To the gyant body of my miſeries.
But try, for I will heare thee; all ſit downe, 'tis death
To any that ſhall dare to interrupt him
In looke, geſture or word.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: And ſuch attention
As is due to the laſt, and the beſt ſtory
That ever was deliver'd, will become you,
The griev'd Ordella, (for all other titles
But take away from that) having from me
Prompted by your laſt parting groane, enquir'd,
What drew it from you, and the cauſe ſoone learn'd:
For ſhee whom barbariſme could deny nothing,
With ſuch prevailing earneſtneſſe deſir'd it,
'Twas not in mee though it had beene my death,
To hide it from her; ſhe I ſay, in whom
All was, that Athens, Rome, or warlike Sparta,
Have regiſtred for good in their beſt women:
But nothing of their ill, knowing her ſelfe
Mark'd out, (I know not by what power, but ſure
A cruell one) to dye, to give you children;
Having firſt with a ſetled countenance
Look'd up to heaven, and then upon her ſelfe,
(It being the next beſt object) and then ſmil'd,
As if her joy in death to doe you ſervice,
Would break forth in deſpight of the much ſorrow
Shee ſhew'd ſhe had to leave you: and then taking
Mee by the hand, this hand which I muſt ever
Love better then I have done, ſince ſhee touch'd it,
Goe, ſaid ſhe, to my Lord, (and to goe to him
Is ſuch a happineſſe I muſt not hope for)
And tell him that hee too much priz'd a trifle
Made only worthy in his love, and her
Thankfull acceptance, for her ſake to robbe
The Orphan Kingdome of ſuch guardians, as
Muſt of neceſſitie deſcend from him;
And therefore in ſome part of recompence
Of his much love, and to ſhew to the world
That 'twas not her fault only, but her fate,
That did deny to let her be the mother
Of ſuch moſt certaine bleſſings: yet for proofe,
She did not envy her, that happy her,
That is appointed to them, her quick end
Should make way for her; which no ſooner ſpoke,
But in a moment this too ready engine
Made ſuch a battery in the choiſeſt caſtle
That ever nature made to defend life,
That ſtrait it ſhooke, and ſunke.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Stay, dares any
Preſume to ſhed a teare before me? or
Aſcribe that worth unto themſelves to merit
To doe ſo for her? I have done, now on.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Falne thus, once more ſhe ſmil'd, as if that death
For her had ſtudied a new way to ſever
The ſoule and body, without ſence of paine;
And then tell him quoth ſhee what you have ſeene,
And with what willingneſſe 'twas done: for which
My laſt requeſt unto him is, that he
Would inſtantly make choyce of one (moſt happy
In being ſo choſen) to ſupply my place,
By whom if heaven bleſſe him with a daughter,
In my remembrance let it beare my name
Which ſaid ſhe di'd.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: I heare this, and yet live;
Heart art thou thunder proofe, wil nothing breake thee?
Shee's dead, and what her entertainment may be
In th'other world without me is uncertaine,
And dare I ſtay here unreſolv'd?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Oh Sir!

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Deare ſonne.

sp.speaker: Pret.
sp.l: Great King.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Unhand me, am I falne
So low, that I have loſt the power to be
Diſpoſer of my owne life?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Be but pleas'd
To borrow ſo much time of ſorrow, as
To call to mind her laſt requeſt, for whom
(I muſt confeſſe a loſſe beyond expreſſion)
You turne your hand upon your ſelfe, 'twas hers
And dying hers, that you ſhould live and happy
In ſeeing little models of your ſelfe,
By matching with another, and will you
Leave any thing that ſhee deſir'd ungranted?
And ſuffer ſuch a life that was laid downe
For your ſake only to be fruitleſſe?

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Oh thou doſt throw charmes upon me, againſt which
I cannot ſtop my eares, beare witneſſe heaven
That not deſire of life, nor love of pleaſure
Nor any future comforts, but to give
Peace to her bleſſed ſpirit in ſatisfying
Her laſt demand, makes mee deferre our meeting,
Which in my choiſe, and ſuddaine choiſe ſhall bee
To all apparant,

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: How? doe I remove one miſchiefe
To draw upon my head a greater?

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Goe, thou only good man, to whom for her ſelfe
Goodneſſe is deare, and prepare to interre it
In her that was; O my heart! my Ordella,
A monument worthy to be the casket
Of ſuch a jewell.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Your command that makes way
Vnto my abſence is a welcome one,
For but your ſelfe there's nothing heere Martell
Can take delight to looke on; yet ſome comfort
Goes back with me, to her, who though ſhe want it
Deſerves all bleſſings. Exit.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: So ſoone to forget
The loſſe of ſuch a wife, beleeve it will
Be cenſur'd in the world.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Pray you no more,
There is no argument you can uſe to croſſe it,
But does increaſe in me ſuch a ſuſpition
I would not cheriſh,—who's that?

sp.speaker: Memb.
sp.l: One, no guard
Can put back from acceſſe, whoſe tongue no threats
Nor praiſes can ſilence, a bold ſuitor and
For that which if you are your ſelfe, a King,
You were made ſo to grant it, Juſtice, Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: With what aſſurance dare you hope for that
Which is deni'd to me? or how can I
Stand bound to be juſt, unto ſuch as are
Beneath mee, that find none from thoſe that are
Above me.

sp.speaker: Memb.
sp.l: There is juſtice, 'twere unfit
That any thing but vengeance ſhould fall on him,
That by his giving way to more then murther,
For my deare fathers death was particide)
Makes it his owne.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: I charge you heare her not.

sp.speaker: Memb.
sp.l: Hell cannot ſtop juſt prayers from entring heaven,
I muſt and will be heard Sir; but remember
That he that by her plot fell, was your brother,
And the place where, your Palace, againſt all
Th'inviolable rites of Hoſpitality,
Your word, a Kings word, given up for his ſafety,
His innocence, his protection, and the Gods
Bound to revenge the impious breach of ſuch
So great and facred bonds; and can you wonder,
(That in not puniſhing ſuch a horrid murther
You did it) that heavens favour is gone from you?
Which never will returne untill his bloud
Be waſh'd away in hers.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Drag hence the wretch.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Forbeare: with what variety
Of torments doe I meete? Oh thou haſt open'd
A booke in which writ downe in bloudy letters,
My conſcience finds that I am worthy of
More then I undergoe, but i'le begin
For my Ordella's ſake, and for thine owne
To make leſſe heavens great anger: thou haſt loſt
A father, I to thee am ſo; the hope
Of a good husband, in mee have one; nor
Be fearfull I am ſtill no man, already
That weakneſſe is gone from me.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: That it might aſide
Have ever growne inſeparably upon thee,
What will you doe? Is ſuch a thing as this
Worthy the lov'd Ordella's place, the daughter
Of a poore Gardiner?

sp.speaker: Memb.
sp.l: Your ſonne.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: The power
To take away that lowneſſe is in me.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Stay yet, for rather then thou ſhalt adde
Inceſt unto thy other ſinnes, I will
With hazard of my owne life utter all
Theodoret was thy brother.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: You deni'd it,
Vpon your oath, nor will I now believe you,
Your Protean turnings cannot change my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Memb.
sp.l: And for me, be aſſur'd the meanes to be.
Revenge on thee vile hag, admits no thought,
But what tends to it.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Is it come to that?
Then have at the laſt refuge; art thou growne
Inſenſible in ill, that thou goeſt on
Without the leaſt compunction? there, take that
To witneſſe that thou hadſt a mother, which
Foreſaw thy cauſe of griefe, and ſad repentance,
That ſo ſoone after bleſt Ordella's death
Without a teare thou canſt imbrace another,
Forgetfull man.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Mine eyes when ſhe is nam'd
Connot forget their tribute, and your gift
Is not unuſefull now

sp.speaker: Lecure.
sp.l: He's paſt all cure, that onely touch is death.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: This night i'le keep it,
To morrow I will ſend it you, and full of my affliction. Exit Thierry.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Is the poyſon mortall?

sp.speaker: Lecure.
sp.l: Above the helpe of phyſick.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: To my wiſh,
Now for our owne ſecurity, you Protaldye
Shall this night poſt towards Auſtracia,
With letters to Theodorets baſtard ſonne,
In which wee will make knowne what for his riſing
We have done to Thierry: no deniall,
Nor no excuſe in ſuch acts muſt bee though of,
Which all diſlike, and all againe commend
When they are brought unto a happy end

div.head: Scoe. 3.

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: No war, no money, no Maſter; baniſh't the Court, not truſted in the City, whipt out of the countrey, in what a triangle runnes our miſery: let mee heare which of you has the beſt voice to beg in, for other hopes or fortunes I ſee you have not; be not nice, nature provided you with tones for the purpoſe, the peoples charity was your heritage, and I would ſee which of you deſerves his birth-right.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Wee underſtand you not Captaine.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: You ſee this cardicue, the laſt and the only quinteſſence of 50 crownes, diſtill'd in the lembicke of your gardage, of which happy piece thou ſhalt be treaſurer: now he that can ſooneſt perſwade him to part with't, enjoyes it, poſſeſſes it, and with it, mee and my future countenance.
If they want art to perſwade it, I'le keepe it my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: So you be not a partiall judge in your owne cauſe, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A match.

I'le begin to you, brave Sir; be proud to make him happy by your liberality, whoſe tongue vouchſafes now to petition, was never heard before leſſe then to command. I
am a ſouldier by profeſſion, a gentleman by birth, and an officer by place, whoſe poverty bluſhes to be the cauſe that ſo high a vertue ſhould deſcend to the pitie of your charitie.
In any caſe keep your high ſtile, it is not charity to ſhame any man, much leſſe a vertue of your eminence, wherefore preſerve your worth, and i'le preſerve my money.

You perſwade? you are ſhallow, give way to merit: ah by the bread of good man, thou haſt a bonny countenance and a blith, promiſing mickle good to a ſicker wombe, that has trod a long and a ſoare ground to meet with friends that will owe much to thy reverence, when they ſhall heare of thy curteſie to their wandring countreyman.
You that will uſe your friends ſo hardly to bring them in debt Sir, will deſerve worſe of a ſtranger, wherefore pead on, pead on I ſay.

It is the welch muſt do't I ſee, comrade man of urſhip, St. Tavy be her patron, the Gods of the mountaines keepe her cow and her cupboard, may ſhe never want the green of the leeke and the fat of the onion, if ſhee part with her bounties to him that is a great deale away from her cozines, and has too big ſuites in law to recover her heritage.

Pardon me Sir, I will have nothing to doe with your ſuites, it comes within the ſtatute of maintenance: home to your cozines, and ſow garlick and hemp-ſeed, the one will ſtop your hunger, the other end your ſuites, gammawaſh comrade, gammawaſh.
Foot he'le hoord all for himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Vitry.
sp.p: Yes, let him; now comes my turne, i'le ſee if he can anſwer mee: ſave you Sir, they ſay you have that I want, money.
And that you are like to want, for ought I perceive yet.

sp.speaker: Vitry.
sp.p: Stand, deliver.
Foot what meane you, you will not rob the Exchequer?

sp.speaker: Vitry.
sp.p: Doe you prate?
Hold, hold, here Captaine.
Why I could have done this before you.
And I.
And I.

sp.speaker: Vitry.
sp.p: You have done this, brave man he proud to make him happy, by the bread of God man thou haſt a bonny countenance, comrade man of u • ſhip, St. Tavy be her patron, cut upon you, you uncurried colts, walking cans that have no ſouls in you, but a little roſin to keepe your ribs ſweet, and hold in liquor.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Why, what would you have us to doe Captaine?

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: Beg, beg, and keepe Conſtables waking, weare out ſtocks and whipcord, mander for buttermilke, dye of the jaundice, yet have the cure about you, lice, large lice, begot of your owne duſt, and the heate of the brick-kills, may you ſtarve, and feare of the gallowes, which is a gentle conſumption to't, only preferre it, or may you fall upon your feare, and be hanged for ſelling thoſe purſes to keepe you from famine whoſe monies my valour empties, and be caſt without other evidence; here is my fort, my caſtle of defence, who comes by ſhall pay me tolle, the firſt purſe is your mittimus ſlaves.
The purſe, foot we'le ſhare in the money Captaine, if any come within a furlong of our fingers.
Did you doubt but wee could ſteale as well as your ſelfe, did not I ſpeake welch?
We are theeves from our cradles, an will dye ſo.

sp.speaker: Vitry.
sp.p: Then you will not beg againe.

sp.speaker: Omnes?
sp.p: Yes, as you did, ſtand, and deliver.
Harke, here comes handſell, 'tis a trade quickly ſet up, and as ſoone caſt downe.

sp.speaker: Vitry.
sp.p: Have goodneſſe in your minds varlets, and to't like men; he that has more money than wee, cannet bee our friend, and I hope there is no law for ſpoyling the enemie.
You need not inſtruct us farther, your example pleads enough.

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: Diſperſe your ſelves, and as their company is, fall on.
Come, there are a band of them, i'le charge ſingle. Exit ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: 'Tis wonderfull dark, I have loſt my man, and dare not call for him, leſt I ſhould have more followers then I would pay wages to; what throwes am I in, in this travaile? theſe be honourable adventure; had I that honeſt blood in my veines againe Queene, that your feats and theſe frights have drain'd from me, honour ſhould pull hard ere it drew me into theſe brakes.

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Hey ho, here's a pang of preferment.

sp.speaker: Devi.
sp.p: Hart, who goes there?

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Hee that has no heart to your acquaintance, what ſhall I doe with my jewels and my letter, my cod-peece, that's too looſe, good, my boots, who iſt that ſpoke to mee? here's a friend.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: We ſhall find that preſently, ſtand, as you love your ſafety ſtand.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: That unlucky word of ſtanding has brought me to all this, hold, or I ſhall never ſtand you.

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: I ſhould know that voice, deliver.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: All that I have is at your ſervice Gentlemen, and much good may it doe you.

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: Zones downe with him, doe you prate?

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Keepe your firſt word as you are Gentlemen, and let me ſtand, alas what doe you meane?
To tye you to us Sir, bind you in the knot of friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Alas Sir, all the phyſick in Europe cannot bind me.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: You ſhould have jewels about you, ſtones, precious ſtones.
Captaine away, there's company within hearing, if you ſtay longer wee are ſurpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: Let the Devill come, i'le pillage this frigot a little better yet.
Foot we are loſt, they are upon us.

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: Ha, upon us, make the leaſt noiſe, 'tis thy parting gaſpe.
Which way ſhall we make Sir?

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: Every man his owne; doe you heare, onely bind me before you goe, and when the companie's paſt, make to this place againe, this karvell ſhould have better ladine in him, you are ſlow, why doe you not tye harder?
You are ſure enough I warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: Darkneſſe befriend you, away.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: What tyrants have I met with? they leave me alone in the darke, yet would not have me cry. I ſhall grow wondrous melancholy if I ſtay long here without company; I was wont to get a nap with ſaying my prayers, i'le ſee if they will worke upon me now; but then if I ſhould talk in my ſleep, and they heare me, they would make a Recorder of my windpipe, ſlit my throate: heaven bee prais'd, I heare ſome noiſe, it may bee new purchaſe, and then I ſhall have fellowes.

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: They are gone paſt hearing, now to taske Devitry, helpe, helpe, as you are men helpe, ſome charitable hand, relieve a poore diſtreſſed miſerable wretch; theeves, wicked theeves have rob'd me, bound me.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Foot would they had gag'd you too, your noiſe will betray us, and fetch them againe.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: What bleſſed tongue ſpake to me, where, where are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: A plague of your bawling throate, we are well enough, if you have the grace to be thankfull for't, doe but ſnore to mee, and 'tis as much as I deſire, to paſſe away time with till morning, then talke as loud as you pleaſe Sir, I am bound not to ſtir, therefore lie ſtill and ſnore I ſay.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: Then you have met with theeves too I ſee.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: And deſire to meet with no more of them.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: Alas what can wee ſuffer more? they are far enough by this time; have they not all, all that we have Sir?

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: No by my faith have they not Sir; I gave them one trick to boote for their learning, my bootes Sir, my bootes, I have ſav'd my ſtock, and my jewels in them, and therefore deſire to heare no more of them.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p:
Now bleſſing on your wit Sir, what a dull ſlave was I, dreampt not of your conveyance? helpe to unbidd me Sir, and
i'le undoe you, my life for yours no worſe theefe than my ſelfe meetes you againe this night.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Reach me thy hands.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: Here Sir, here, I could beate my braines out, that could not thinke of bootes, bootes Sir, wide topt boots, I ſhall love them the better whilſt I live; but are you ſure your jewels are here Sir?

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Sure ſayſt thou? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.l: So ho, illo ho. Within ſouldiers.
Here Captaine, here.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Foote what doe you meane Sir?

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: A trick to boote, ſay you; here you dull ſlaves, purchaſe, purchaſe the ſoule of the rock, diamonds, ſparkling diamonds.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: I am betraid, loſt, paſt recovery loſt, as you are men.

sp.speaker: Devit,
sp.p: Nay Rooke, ſince you will be prating, wee'l ſhare your carion with you, have you any other conveyance now Sir?
Foot here are letters, epiſtles, familiar epiſtles, wee'l ſee what treaſure is in them, they are ſeal'd ſure,

sp.speaker: Pro,
sp.p: Gentlemen, as you are gentlemen ſpare my letters, and take all willingly, all: i'le give you a releaſe, a generall releaſe, and meete you here too morrow with as much more.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: Nay, ſince you have your trickes, and your conveyances, wee will not leave a wrinckle of you unſearcht.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Harke, there comes company, you will be betraid, as you love your ſafeties beat out my braines, I ſhall betray you elſe.

sp.speaker: Devitry.
sp.p: Treaſon, unheard of treaſon monſtrous, monſtrous villanies.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: I confeſſe my ſelfe a traytor, ſhew your ſelves good ſubjects, and hang mee up for't.
If it be treaſon, the diſcovery will get our pardon Captaine.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: Would wee were all loſt, hang'd, quarter'd to ſave this one, one innocent Prince; Thierry's poyſon'd, by his mother poyſon'd, the Miſtris to this ſtallion, who by that poyſon ne're ſhall ſleep againe.
Foot let us mince him by piecemeale, till he eate himſelfe up.
Let us dig out his heart with needles, and halfe broile him, like a muſſell.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Such another and I prevent you, my blood's ſetled already.

sp.speaker: Devit.
sp.p: Here's that ſhall remove it, toade, viper, drag him unto Martell, unnaturall parricide, cruell, bloody woman.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: On you dogfiſh, leech, caterpiller.

sp.speaker: Deuit.
sp.p: A longer ſight of him will make my rage turne pitie, and with his ſuddaine end prevent revenge and torture, wicked, wicked Brunhalt. Exit.
Not ſleep at all, no meanes.
No art can doe it.

sp.speaker: Bawdb.
sp.l: I will aſſure you hee can ſleep no more
Then a hooded hawke, a centinell to him,
Or one of the City Conſtables are tops.
How came he ſo?

sp.speaker: Bawdb.
sp.l: They are too wiſe that dare know,
Somethings amiſſe, heaven helpe all.
What cures has he?

sp.speaker: Bawdb.
sp.l: Armies of thoſe wee call Phyſicians, ſome with gliſters,
Some with lettice caps, ſome poſſet drinkes ſome pills,
Twenty conſulting here about a drench,
As many here to blood him;
Then comes a Don of Spaine, and he preſcribes
More cooling opium then would kill a turk,
Or quench a whore i'th dogdayes; after him
A wife Italian, and he cries, tie unto him
A woman of foureſcore, whoſe bones are marble,
Whoſe blond ſnow water, not ſo much heate about her
As may conceive a prayer: after him
An Engliſh Doctor, with a bunch of pot hearbes,
And he cries out Endiffe and ſuckery,
With a few mallow rootes and buttermilke,
And talkes of oyle made of a Churchmans charity,
Yet ſtill he wakes.
But your good honour
Has a prayer in ſtore if all ſhould faile.

sp.speaker: Bawdb.
sp.l: I could have prayed, and handſomely,
But age and an ill memory.
Has ſpoll'd your primmer.

sp.speaker: Bawdb.
sp.l: Yet if there be a man of faith i'th Court,
An can pray for a penſion.

div.stage: Enter Thierry on a bed, with Doctors and Attendants.

sp.l: Here's the King Sir,
And thoſe that will pray without pay.

sp.speaker: Bawdb.
sp.l: Then pray for me too.

sp.speaker: 1. Doct.
sp.l: How does your Grace feele your ſelfe now?

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: 1. Doct.
sp.l: Nothing at all Sir, but your fancy.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Tell me,
Can ever theſe eyes more ſhut up in ſlumbers,
Aſſure my ſoule there is ſleepe? is there night
And reſt for humane labours? doe not you
And all the world as I doe, out-ſtare time,
And live like funerall lampes never extinguiſht?
Is there a grave, and doe not flatter me,
Nor feare to tell mee truth; and in that grave
Is there a hope I ſhall ſleepe, can I die,
Are not my miſeries immortall? oh
The happines of him that drinkes his water
After his weary day, and ſleepes for ever,
Why doe you crucifie mee thus with faces,
And gaping ſtrangely upon one another,
When ſhall I reſt?

sp.speaker: 2. Doct.
sp.l: O Sir be patient.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Am I not patient? have I not endur'd
More then a maingy dog among your doſſes?
Am I not now your patient? ye can make
Unwholſome fooles ſleepe for a guarded foot-cloth,
Whores for a hot ſinne offering; yet I muſt crave
That feede ye, and protect ye, and proclame ye,
Becauſe my power is farre above your ſearching,
Are my diſeaſes ſo? can ye cure none
But thoſe of equall ignorance, dare yee kill me?

sp.speaker: 1. Doct.
sp.l: We doe beſeech your grace bee more reclaim'd,
This talke doth but diſtemper you.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Well, I will die
In ſpight of all your potions; one of you ſleepe,
Lie downe and ſleep here, that I may behold
What bleſſed reſt it is my eyes are rob'd of:
See, hee can ſleepe, ſleep any where, ſleep now,
When hee that wakes for him can never ſlumber,
I'ſt not a dainty eaſe?

sp.speaker: 2. Doct.
sp.l: Your Grace ſhall feele it.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: O never I, never, the eyes of heaven
See but their certaine motions, and then ſleepe,
The rages of the Ocean have their ſlumbers,
And quiet ſilver calmes; each violence
Crownes in his end a peace, but my fixt fires
Shall never, never ſet, who's that?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: No woman,
Mother of miſchiefe, no the day ſhall die firſt,
And all good things live in a worſe then thou art,
Ere thou ſhalt ſleepe, doſt thou ſee him?

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Yes, and curſe him,
And all that love him foole, and all live by him.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Why art thou ſuch a monſter?

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Why art thou
So tame a knave to aske me?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Hope of hell,
By this faire holy light, and all his wrongs
Which are above thy yeares, almoſt thy 〈◊〉
Thou ſhalt not reſt, not feele more what is pity,
Know nothing neceſſary, meet no ſociety.
But what ſhall curſe and crucifie thee, feele in thy ſelfe
Nothing but what thou art, bane and bad conſcience,
Till this man reſt; but for whoſe reverence
Becauſe thou art his mother, I would ſay
Whore, this ſhall bee, doe ye nod? i'le waken ye
With my ſwords point.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: I wiſh no more of heaven,
Nor hope no more, but a ſufficient anger
To torture thee.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: See, ſhe that makes you ſee Sir
And to your miſery ſtill ſee your mother,
The mother of your woes Sir, of your waking,
The mother of your peoples cries and curſes,
Your murdering mother, your malicious mother.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Phyſicians, halfe my ſtate to ſleepe an houre now;
Is it ſo mother?

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Yes it is ſo ſonne;
And were it yet againe to doe, it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: She nods againe, ſwing her.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: But mother,
For yet I love that reverence, and to death
Dare not forget you have been ſo; was this,
This endleſſe miſerie, this cureleſſe malice,
This ſnatching from mee all my youth together,
All that you made mee for, and happy mothers
Crown'd with eternall time are proud to finiſh,
Done by your will?

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: It was, and by that will.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: O mother, doe not loſe your name, forget not
The touch of nature in you, tendernes
'Tis all the ſoule of woman, all the ſweetnes;
Forget not I beſeech you what are children,
Nor how you have gron'd for them, to what love
They are borne inheritors, with what care kept,
And as they riſe to ripeneſſe ſtill remember
How they impe out your age; and 〈◊〉 time calls you,
That as an Autumne flower you fall, forget not
How round about your hearſe they hang like penons.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Holy foole,
Whoſe patience to prevent my wrongs has kill'd thee,
Preach not to me of puniſhments or feares,
Or what I ought to be, but what I am,
A woman in her liberall will defeated,
In all her greatnes croſt, in pleaſures blaſted,
My angers have beene laught at, my ends ſlighted,
And all thoſe glories that had crown'd my fortunes,
Suffer'd by blaſted vertue to be ſcatter'd,
I am the fruitfull mother of theſe angers,
And what ſuch have done, reade, and know thy ruine.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Heaven forgive you.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: She tels you true, for millions of her miſchiefes
Are now apparent, Protaldye wee have taken
An equall agent with her, to whoſe care
After the damn'd defeat on you, ſhe truſted
The bringing in of Leonor the baſtard
Sonne to your murder'd brother; her phyſitian
By this time is attacht to that damn'd devill.

sp.speaker: Meſſen.
sp.l: 'Tis like hee will bee ſo, for ere we came,
Fearing an equall juſtice for his miſchiefes,
He drench't himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: He did like one of mine then.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Muſt I ſtill ſee theſe miſeries, no night
To hide me from their horrors, that Protaldy
See juſtice fall upon.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Now I could ſleepe too.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ile give you yet more poppy, bring the Lady
And heaven in her embraces; gives him quiet
Madam, unvaile your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: I doe forgive you,
And though you ſought my blood, yet ile pray for you,

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Art thou alive?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Now could you ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: For ever.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Go carry her without wink of ſleepe, or quiet,
Where her ſtrong knave Protaldy's broke oth wheele,
And let his cryes & roares be muſick toner,
I mean to waken her.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Do her no wrong.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Nor right as you love juſtice.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: I will thinke,
And if there be new curſes in old nature,
I have a ſoule dare ſend them.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Keepe her waking.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.p: What's that appeares ſo ſweetly? their's that face.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Be moderate Lady.

sp.speaker: Their.
sp.l: That angels face.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Go neraer.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Martell, I cannot laſt long, ſee the ſoule,
I ſee it perfectly of my Ordella,
The heavenly figure of her ſweetneſſe there,
Forgive mee Gods, it comes, divineſt ſubſtance,
Kneele, kneele, kneele every one, Saint of thy ſexe,
If it be for my cruelty thou comeſt,
Do ye ſee her hoe?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and you ſhall know her.

sp.speaker: Thier,
sp.l: Downe, downe againe, to bee reveng'd for bloud,
Sweet ſpirit I am ready, ſhe ſmiles on me,
O bleſſed ſigne of peace.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Goe neerer Lady.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: I come to make you happy

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Heare you that Sir?
She comes to crowne my ſoule away, get ſacrifice,
Whil'ſt I with holy honours.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Shee's alive ſir.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: In everlaſting life I know it friend,
O happy, happy ſoule.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Alas I live Sir
A mortall woman ſtill.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Can ſpirits weepe too?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Shee's no ſpirit Sir, pray kiſſe her; Lady,
Be very gentle to him.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Stay, ſhe is warme,
And by my life the ſame lips tell me brightneſſe,
Are you the ſame Ordella ſtill?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: The ſame Sir.
Whom heavens and my good Angell ſtaid from ruine.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Kiſſe me againe.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: The ſame ſtill, ſtill your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe, I know her now Martell; ſit downe ſweet,
O bleſt and happieſt woman, a dead ſlumber
Begins to creep upon me, O my jewell!

sp.speaker: Ordella,
sp.l: O ſleepe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: My joyes are too much for me.

sp.speaker: Meſſen.
sp.l: Brunhalt impatient of her conſtraint to fee
Protaldye tortur'd, has chokt her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: No more, her ſinnes goe with her.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Love I muſt die, I faint, cloſe up my glaſſes.

sp.speaker: 1. Doct.
sp.l: The Queen faints too, and deadly.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: One dying kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: My laſt Sir, and my deareſt, and now
Cloſe my eyes too.

sp.speaker: Thier.
sp.l: Thou perfect woman,
Martell, the Kingdome's yours, take Memberge to you,
And keep my line alive; nay weep not Lady,
Take me, I goe.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.l: Take mee too, farewell honour.

sp.speaker: 2. Doct.
sp.l: They are gone for ever.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: The peace of happy ſoules goe after them,
Beare them to their laſt beds, whilſt I ſtudy
A tombe to ſpeake their loves; whilſt old time laſteth,
I am your King in ſorrowes.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We your ſubjects.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Devitry, for your ſervice, bee neere us,
Whip out theſe inſtruments of this mad mother
From Court, and all good people; and becauſe
She was borne noble, let that title find her
A private grave, but neither tongue nor honour:
And now lead on, they that ſhall read this ſtory,
Shall find that vertue lives in good, not glory. Exeunt Omnes.
